findings.label: Likely Duplicate Payments
findings.detail: 231 high-confidence duplicate groups with same supplier, amount, date and reference (3+ copies) (after filtering 674 CSV republication artifacts)
findings.context_note: Quarterly CSV overlaps (same transaction appearing in 2 files) have been filtered out. Remaining duplicates show 3+ identical copies, which are more likely genuine overpayments.

findings.label: Suspected Split Payments
findings.detail: 5 instances of 3+ payments just below approval thresholds in the same week
findings.context_note: Split payment detection has a high false-positive rate. Batch processing, staged invoices, and legitimate recurring payments can all trigger this pattern. FOI request for procurement approval chain recommended before drawing conclusions.

findings.label: Round-Number Payments (>£5K)
findings.detail: 94 exact round-number payments over £5,000 — may indicate estimates rather than invoiced amounts

findings.label: Year-End Spending Pattern
findings.detail: lfrs spent 2.1x their monthly average in March (£874.6K above normal). Note: UK councils operate on April–March fiscal years, so elevated March spending is common as departments finalise annual budgets. Spikes above 3x warrant further scrutiny.
findings.context_note: March spending above the monthly average is expected for UK councils on April–March fiscal years. Compare against prior years' March figures for meaningful analysis.

findings.label: Rapid Payment Suppliers
findings.detail: 13 suppliers receive payments every <14 days on average. Top: Oscar Associates (Uk) Ltd (5.0 day avg, 10 payments, £19.4K)

findings.label: Benford's Law Analysis
findings.detail: Digit distribution across 13,653 transactions shows χ²=795.75 (statistically significant due to large sample size), but max digit deviation is only 5.0% — within the normal range for UK council spending patterns. No practical evidence of fabricated invoices.
findings.context_note: Chi-squared values on samples of 13,653+ transactions are naturally inflated and will almost always show statistical significance. The max digit deviation (5.0%) is a more meaningful indicator — deviations under 5% are typical for legitimate council spending.

findings.label: Second-Digit Benford's Anomaly
findings.detail: Second-digit distribution across 15,128 transactions shows p < 0.001 (highly significant). Digit 0 deviates 2.67% from Nigrini's expected distribution. Second-digit tests are more discriminating than first-digit for detecting round-number bias and fabricated invoices.
findings.context_note: Benford's second-digit analysis (Nigrini, 2012) uses chi-squared with 9 df. Critical values: 16.92 (p=0.05), 21.67 (p=0.01), 27.88 (p=0.001). n=15,128.

key_findings.title: 2 suppliers with clock-like payment regularity
key_findings.description: These suppliers receive payments at near-identical intervals (std dev <5 days). Top: Longton Protective Clothing — every 28.0 days (21 payments, £1.2K)

key_findings.title: NPOWER: 774 transactions totalling £1.7M
key_findings.description: Averaging £2.2K per transaction — the council's most frequent supplier

signals.signal: Year-end spike: 8.7x monthly average in March

fraud_triangle.methodology: Fraud triangle (Cressey 1953): screening tool synthesising existing DOGE analysis signals. Not an accusation of fraud.
